3791122099.resolved_title: It Came From the ’70s: The Story of Your Grandma’s Weird Couch
3791122099.excerpt: Where did the Grandma Couch—which is somehow both conservative and flamboyant at the same—come from?

2.caption: Top: This sofa’s shape, structure, and colors are almost identical to my grandmother’s couch.

3.caption: A 1958 still from the TV series “Gunsmoke” shows Amanda Blake as Miss Kitty and Milburn Stone as Doc Adams.

4.caption: A found snapshot from 1977 shows a grandpa hanging out with his grandkids on a brown-tone floral Colonial-style wingback sofa.

5.caption: Depending on the meme, everyone—or everyone’s grandma—had this sofa. Here, the busy pattern on the synthetic velour includes an old-timey clock. At least, I think that’s what’s happening.

6.credit: Photo Via classic_film on Flickr/Creative Commons
6.caption: The “floral sofa” in this Sears Open Hearth Country Home ad, which appeared in the May 1977 issue of “Redbook,” is the closest advertising image I’ve found to the Grandma Couch.

7.caption: An early ’70s kitchen in Arizona with a patriotic eagle, Knotty Pine cabinets, modified Windsor chairs, and a Harvest Gold and Burnt Orange color palette.

8.caption: On the right side of this 1970 image of a Montgomery Ward floor, you can see a brown floral couch similar to my grandma’s, as well as a Colonial Revival coffee table that resembles hers, but with different hardware. In the background is an orange plaid couch.

9.caption: This 1970s catalog page shows Spanish or Mediterranean style furniture, heavy with carved wood gewgaws.

10.caption: In this 1970s ad, a stylish young woman holds a book on a floral Grandma Couch while an unseen companion pets her golden retriever, who rests on shag carpeting surrounded by Colonial Revival furniture.

11.caption: The Spring/Summer 1976 Sears catalog shows a family touring the home of Founding Father John Adams in Quincy, Massachusetts.

12.caption: Another 1977 ad for the Sears Open Hearth Country Home furniture line. Tartan plaid made of indestructible synthetic weaves, Windsor chairs, red tile, braided rugs, and patriotic colors were all a part of the “Spirit of ’76” Colonial Revival.

13.credit: Julius Shulman, © J. Paul Getty Trust. Getty Research Institute, Los Angeles

14.caption: An article in the September 1958 edition of “Family Circle” extols the virtues of affordable Colonial Revival and Early American furniture.

15.caption: Game birds roost among wildflowers on this fake-velour ’70s Grandma Couch.

16.caption: A young dad cuddles with his baby on a Colonial Revival sofa with a brown Herculon plaid fabric in this 1979 vernacular photo.

17.caption: Pam Kueber’s favorite “Bicentennial Chic” room from a mid-1970s Ethan Allen catalog.

18.caption: This 1952 ad for Formica countertops shows the modern material paired with Knotty Pine cabinets and paneling. The ad text promotes “the warmth and charm of the early American kitchen.”

19.caption: Christine’s Creations in Woodstock, Georgia, upcycled this grandma furniture set into stylish outdoor furniture. But who’s to say how long apple green and apple red will be en vogue?

20.caption: A Grandma Couch meme shared by comedian, actor, and rapper Mike Epps on Facebook.

21.caption: This post originally appeared on Collectors Weekly and was published August 27, 2018. This article is republished here with permission.Interested in getting your own collector’s items appraised from experts and professionals?Value my stuff

3504604477.excerpt: We know from Nihon Shoki (the Chronicles of Japan) that Doncho, a Korean Buddhist priest, brought Chinese paper and ink to Japan in 610 C.E.

1.caption: The Nihon Shoki records the arrival of Chinese paper and ink to Japan.

2.caption: Today, artisans continue to use traditional techniques to make washi.1

3.caption: Giving out shūgi-bukuro envelopes and New Year’s cards are traditional ways of using paper.

4.caption: Japanese paper companies consider how different pens, like fountain pens, pair with their paper.

5.caption: Japanese notebooks have many options for sheet style and paper variety.

6.caption: The Hobonichi Techo is a planner that can be paired with charming covers that are released every year.

7.caption: Some might use a techo as a simple way to keep track of tasks, while others use their planners for daily art challenges.

8.caption: Kokuyo Campus Notebooks are some of our most popular notebooks. Campus Paracuruno Notebooks feature slanted pages that makes it easier to flip through the pages.

9.caption: Kokuyo Perpanep Notebooks contain different paper types, like ultra-smooth Tsurutsuru or textured Zarazara.

10.caption: Compared to Sarasara paper, Shikkari paper is softer and thicker. It works well with pencils and ballpoints.

11.caption: Tomoe River paper has a triple-layer design that prevents ink from absorbing all the way through the paper.

12.caption: If inks take too long to dry on your Hobonichi Techo planner, try using a sheet of blotter paper or quick-drying ballpoint pens.

13.caption: The production process of Tomoe River paper changed in 2020, resulting in two versions of the paper.

14.caption: Tomoe River paper is used in our Kanso Sasshi booklets and Kanso Noto Notebooks.

15.caption: MD Notebooks are Midori's flagship product.

16.caption: MD Cotton Paper is made with 20% cotton pulp and has a softer, bouncier texture.

17.caption: The TRAVELER'S notebook is a refillable leather cover that can be customized with different notebook inserts and accessories.
